page.title: 13POLWARTH FAUNA
page.content: FOXES, BADGERS, HARES, RABBITS ARE ALL IN EVIDENCE. RABBITS SEEM TO BE ON THE INCREASE AGAIN, THOUGH NOT IN THE QUANTITIES THAT BEFORE THE 1ST. WORLD WAR ALLOWED THEM TO BE SENT 200 AT A TIME IN HAMPERS THRICE WEEKLY BY RAIL FROM MARCHMONT STATION TO THE BIG CITIES. RABBIT TRAPPING WAS A MAN'S SPECIFIC JOB. MANY SMALLER MAMMALS ARE TO BE FOUND. MOLES, MICE, RATS, WEASELS ETC., ADDERS ARE SOMETIMES ENCOUNTERED ON THE MOOR & FROGS, TOADS & LIZARDS ARE SEEN. A NUMBER OF BEEHIVES WERE AT MARCHMONT & ON THE MOOR. 1985 HOWEVER WAS NOT A GOOD SUMMER FOR BEES. THE SUMMER WAS NOT TYPICAL; NOR WAS LAST WINTER WHICH WAS LESS VIGOROUS THAN SOUTHERN ENGLAND & NEVER HAD A ROAD BLOCKED BT SNOW.
